description: From Middle English extenden, from Anglo-Norman extendre, estendre, from Latin extendō (“I stretch out”).

verbs.description: extend (third-person singular simple present extends, present participle extending, simple past and past participle extended)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To possess a certain extent; to cover an amount of space.
examples: The desert extended for miles in all directions.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to increase in extent.
(transitive) To cause to last for a longer period of time.
(transitive) To bestow; to offer; to impart; to apply.
examples: to extend sympathy to the suffering
to extend credit to a valued customer

entries.meaning: To increase in quantity by weakening or adulterating additions.
examples: […]  the exalted morality of those virtuous brethren in the trade who, with consciences as weak as their own "extended" liquors, sought to convince him that to reduce the drink was a mercy to the poor deluded toper.

entries.meaning: (UK, law) To value, as lands taken by a writ of extent in satisfaction of a debt; to assign by writ of extent.
(object-oriented programming) Of a class: to be an extension or subtype of, or to be based on, a prototype or a more abstract class.
examples: The classes Person and Dog extend the class Animal.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, US, military) To reenlist for a further period.
examples: Two years later, back to amtracs, this time at Camp Schwab, Okinawa, and I liked it so much I extended.
